channel.title: Comments on: Building meaning for momentum from discussions, definitions, and data.
channel.description: iteration, making, building, and coding in education

item.title: By: Andy Rundquist (@arundquist)
item.dc:creator: Andy Rundquist (@arundquist)
item.description: Recently I asked some non-science colleagues of mine to reflect on whether they used "momentum" or "energy" more colloquially. I thought it was really interesting, as I found I couldn't get out of my physics head when it came to those words. Many of my colleagues see them as interchangeable ("let's keep the momentum/energy going") while others clearly use one much more than the other.
item.content:encoded: Recently I asked some non-science colleagues of mine to reflect on whether they used “momentum” or “energy” more colloquially. I thought it was really interesting, as I found I couldn’t get out of my physics head when it came to those words. Many of my colleagues see them as interchangeable (“let’s keep the momentum/energy going”) while others clearly use one much more than the other.
